items.title: This free web-based image editor gives Photoshop a run for its money
items.summary:
[ AI image editing is currently popular, but traditional image editors are still essential. ]
[ Many devices lack good image editors beyond basic functionalities. ]
[ Photopea is a free, browser-based image editor that requires no accounts or payments to use. ]
[ Photopea can be accessed from any device for quick image editing. ]

items.title: M4 MacBook Air 2025 review: The perfect laptop for most consumers
items.summary:
- Apple unveiled the new M4 MacBook Air laptops, including a 15-inch model with 16GB memory and 512GB storage.
- The M4 chip offers "23x faster performance" compared to older Intel chips, but minimal speed gains over the M2 and M3 in everyday tasks.
- The laptops feature upgrades beneficial for remote workers, although many improvements are just slight spec increases.

items.title: ‘I caught a baby wombat’: U.S. influencer Sam Jones was roundly condemned for her wildlife stunt in Australia
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- U.S. influencer Sam Jones filmed herself taking a baby wombat from its mother in Australia, sparking widespread outrage.
- The video showed her holding the distressed animal, while laughing was heard in the background.
- Jones claimed she returned the baby wombat unharmed, defending her actions against criticism.
- A petition for her deportation gained over 39,000 signatures, leading to reports that she has left Australia.

items.title: You can now watch a full Metallica concert on Apple Vision Pro
items.summary:
- Apple Vision Pro users can watch Metallica's 2024 Mexico City concert with immersive 180-degree video and Spatial Audio.
- The concert was filmed on September 29 during the sold-out finale of Metallica’s M72 World Tour.
- The concert features fan favorites like “One” and “Enter Sandman.”
- Apple claims the experience feels like being front row, backstage, or even on stage with the band.
- The Vision Pro launched in early 2024 but has seen lukewarm sales.
- Apple is now rolling out features to attract everyday consumers, utilizing advanced filming technology for the concert experience.

items.title: How Influencer Brandon Edelman made $768,000 in a year—and what he actually took home
UN report reveals alarming extent of Iran’s increased surveillance of women
items.author: null
items.summary:
- Iran relies on electronic surveillance and public reporting to enforce mandatory hijab laws.
- The UN report comes after protests sparked by the death of Mahsa Amini, citing ongoing systematic discrimination against women.
- Surveillance methods include drone monitoring, facial recognition, and a mobile app for reporting hijab infractions.
- Over 618 women have been arrested under the renewed enforcement plan since April 2024, amidst rising social unrest and economic issues in Iran.

items.title: Got a road toll text? Don’t click on this ‘smishing’ scam
items.summary:
- State officials warn about a rise in scam road toll texts attempting to gather financial information.
- These scams, known as smishing, use SMS to trick individuals into sending money or personal data.
- Louisiana Attorney General Liz Murrill confirmed she received a fake toll text and emphasized that it is a scam.
- Even states without tolls, like Vermont, have seen these scams, misleading travelers.
- Cybersecurity firm Palo Alto Networks noted over 10,000 domains registered for such scams.
- The scams impersonate toll services across at least 10 U.S. states and in Ontario, Canada.
- The FBI previously issued warnings about similar scams and advised recipients to report and delete the texts.

items.title: Siri’s delay is an artifact of Apple’s unsure AI footing—and more
Block Party offers tool for optimizing social media privacy
West Virginia football coach Rich Rodriguez isn’t here for locker room dances
items.summary:
- West Virginia football coach Rich Rodriguez discourages locker room dances on TikTok for his players.
- He emphasizes a focus on football rather than social media trends, stating it's not the image he wants for the program.
- Rodriguez allows players to use TikTok but opposes dancing on it, suggesting it distracts from winning games.
- Some critics argue this stance could limit athletes' branding opportunities and infringe on their freedoms.
- Despite Rodriguez's stance, some players continue to balance TikTok popularity with their athletic careers successfully.

items.title: Why DeepSeek’s arrival looks like a key moment for safe AI
items.author: Donnchadh Casey
items.summary:
- The AI industry is rapidly evolving with new tools and features becoming common, particularly with OpenAI's new Deep Research tool. 
- A Gartner forecast predicts that 33% of enterprise software will integrate agentic AI by 2028, significantly up from less than 1% in 2024. 
- 76% of C-suite executives believe their AI cybersecurity measures require improvement, raising concerns over data privacy and security, particularly concerning foreign AI entities.
- The emergence of China's DeepSeek has highlighted security issues in AI and the vulnerability of AI models to attacks.
- Implementing security measures alongside AI development is crucial as bad actors often exploit new technologies for malicious purposes.

items.title: Social media addicts: Here are tips to stop wasting time on apps
items.summary:
- Many smartphone users spend excessive time on social media apps like Instagram and TikTok.
- Social media and smartphones can be addictive, making it difficult to reduce usage, especially for younger individuals.
- Suggested techniques include deleting time-wasting apps and utilizing built-in screen time controls on smartphones.

items.title: Match Group’s new CEO admits the company’s dating apps have too often ‘felt like a numbers game’
items.author: Spencer Rascoff
items.summary:
- Match Group's new CEO Spencer Rascoff addressed employee concerns about user experience in a letter.
- Rascoff acknowledges dating apps feeling like a 'numbers game', prioritizing metrics over user connections.
- He emphasizes that future decisions must prioritize user experience and trust.
- Outlined five priorities for transformation: Users first, innovate quickly, details matter, prioritizing transparency, safety & authenticity, and the significance of human connection.
- The company saw success during the pandemic but has faced challenges as users shifted back to in-person interactions.

items.title: The future of AI isn’t the model—it’s the system
items.summary:
- The focus of AI development is shifting from just creating smarter models to building complex systems around them.
- A new autonomous agent system called Manus was released by Butterfly Effect, capable of executing tasks without human supervision.
- Mistral, a French AI company, aims to connect various AI systems to improve enterprise efficiency and has plans to grow its U.S. customer base significantly by 2025.
- Google DeepMind introduced Gemini Robotics, a model aimed at giving robots the ability to reason and perform tasks in the physical world, raising concerns about safety and autonomy.

items.title: Intel taps industry veteran as newest CEO in latest comeback attempt
StudentAid.gov website went down, following mass layoffs at Department of Education
items.author: Collin Binkley, Jocelyn Gecker
items.summary:
- StudentAid.gov experienced an hours-long outage on Wednesday, affecting users trying to complete the FAFSA form for financial aid.
- The outage coincided with significant layoffs at the Department of Education, with over 300 staff cut from Federal Student Aid, affecting IT support for the FAFSA.
- The Education Department did not provide details about the outage, which may have been impacted by the recent layoffs.
- Previous technical issues with the FAFSA have drawn criticism from lawmakers, and concerns exist regarding their impact on college enrollment, although freshman enrollment has increased compared to last year.

items.title: This volunteer crew is on a mission to fix Wikipedia’s worst celebrity photos
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Many celebrity Wikipedia pages feature blurry or unflattering photos due to restrictions on image sourcing.
- Professional photographers typically sell their images, making high-quality portraits scarce on Wikipedia.
- WikiPortraits is a group of volunteer photographers aiming to improve celebrity images on the site by capturing high-quality photos at events like Sundance and SXSW.
- The initiative has grown to over 30 photographers, covering major festivals and providing nearly 5,000 freely licensed portraits.
- Celebrities have responded positively, with instances reported where they appreciate the effort to update their images.

items.title: Cisco’s chief product officer explains the company’s transformation around AI
items.author: Jeetu Patel
items.summary:
- Cisco has transitioned from being primarily known for networking technology to focusing on AI-driven solutions.
- The company made a $28 billion acquisition of big data firm Splunk to enhance its AI capabilities.
- Jeetu Patel, appointed as chief product officer, emphasizes the importance of speed and adaptation in the evolving tech landscape.
- Patel predicts a division in companies based on their adaptability to AI: those that thrive and those that struggle.

items.title: MrBeast’s chocolate empire is making more money than his YouTube channel
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- MrBeast, also known as Jimmy Donaldson, is the most-subscribed YouTuber globally, but his main income now comes from his chocolate brand, Feastables.
- Feastables generated $251 million in sales and over $20 million in profit last year, while his media business reported similar revenue but lost nearly $80 million.
- MrBeast's average video costs between $3 million and $4 million, making it challenging to recoup production costs with a limited video release schedule.
- Feastables is projected to triple in size in a couple of years, while media revenue will make up only one-fifth of total sales by 2026.
- Beast Industries, MrBeast's company, secured over $450 million in funding and is seeking an additional $200 million for a $5 billion valuation, focusing on consumer products instead of just viral videos.
- Future products include beverages, a new snack brand, and cereal, with plans to expand into mobile gaming by next year.

items.title: Try these hybrid tools for thinking on paper
items.summary:
- The article discusses the benefits of hybrid tools for note-taking that combine the feel of paper with digital organization.
- Highlights a specialized paper tablet from Remarkable that mimics the feel of writing on paper but offers digital advantages such as searchability and cloud syncing.
- Features of the device include customizable stylus settings, distraction-free environment, PDF annotation capabilities, and various templates for organization.
- Drawbacks mentioned include its premium price ($579), single-purpose functionality, and slower page turn speeds compared to tablets.

items.title: Protecting the Future of the Internet
items.author: Matthew Prince, Brendan Vaughan
items.summary:
- Matthew Prince, Cofounder and CEO of Cloudflare, discusses the future of the internet.
- Cloudflare powers a quarter of the global internet, serving over 300 cities in 100+ countries.
- The conversation addresses challenges like AI-powered bots and cybersecurity risks.

items.title: Tech workers in Kenya hold vigil for TikTok content moderator who died
items.summary:
- Technology workers in Kenya held a vigil for Ladi Anzaki Olubunmi, a TikTok content moderator who died under unclear circumstances.
- Olubunmi's body was found in her home after three days, and she had reportedly complained of fatigue and wanted to return to Nigeria.
- Teleperformance Kenya stated that they did not deny her leave, but her family claims she only traveled once in three years.
- Content moderators in Kenya have described poor working conditions, including low pay and lack of mental health support.
- Former Facebook moderators have sued over their working conditions, highlighting the challenges faced in the industry.

items.title: Apple successfully blocks Match from data in India antitrust case
items.summary:
- Apple successfully blocks Match and other startups from accessing sensitive information in an India antitrust case.
- The Competition Commission of India's investigation found Apple possibly exploited its dominant position in the app store market.
- The CCI's final ruling is pending, which may lead to fines or changes in Apple's practices.
- Match claimed excessive redactions in Apple's submissions, but the CCI ruled in favor of Apple, citing potential harm to its business.

items.title: TikTok’s comment sections are being flooded with copy-pasted Christian messages
items.summary:
- TikTok has seen an influx of copy-and-pasted Christian comments in its comment sections.
- These comments often include messages about Jesus Christ and evangelism, frequently repeating phrases.
- The origin of this trend remains unclear, leading to speculation about whether it is driven by bots, religious individuals, or organizations.
- Users express frustration over the sudden prevalence of these messages, especially while casually browsing.
- The trend has resulted in both questions and satirical responses, with variations on the main message appearing in the comments.

items.title: Moonvalley launches an AI video generator built for moviemaking
items.author: Naeem Talukdar
items.summary:
- Moonvalley launched Marey, an AI video generator for Hollywood studios, aiming to speed up production and reduce costs.
- Marey is unique due to its exclusive training data from licensed content, avoiding copyright issues.
- The model outputs high-definition video, addressing challenges faced by other models that typically use lower-quality footage.
- Unlike typical video generators, Marey allows filmmakers to use storyboards or keyframes for input, enhancing professional workflows.
- Pilot programs are underway with brands to generate custom video content, including commercials.

items.title: NASA’s new AI satellites could revolutionize disaster response
A new wearable from dating app RAW promises to track your partner’s emotions in real time
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- The RAW ring, developed by the dating app RAW, allows couples to track each other’s emotions in real time.
- The wearable tracks heartbeat, vitals, and detects emotional cues, functioning like a digital mood ring for partners.
- Expected to launch in late 2025 or early 2026, with pricing yet to be announced.
- Concerns exist regarding privacy and relationship dynamics as couples share emotional data.

items.title: Box CEO Aaron Levie finds a middle ground on tech policy during Trump’s second term
How the Trump administration plans to use algorithms to target protesters
items.summary:
- The U.S. State Department is planning to use technology to suppress protests against the Trump administration.
- The "Catch and Revoke" plan by Marco Rubio aims to utilize AI analysis of social media to revoke visas of foreign nationals.
- Mahmoud Khalil, a former grad student, is highlighted as a target for this initiative due to his participation in protests.
- Experts warn that using AI to analyze social media could lead to significant false positives and raise privacy concerns.

items.title: Military AI is here. Some experts are worried
items.summary:
- Scale AI awarded a multimillion-dollar deal to develop Thunderforge for the U.S. Department of Defense.
- Thunderforge aims to integrate AI into military operational planning with claims of providing the U.S. military leaders a technological advantage.
- Experts express concern over the potential catastrophic outcomes of AI in military use, with predictions of risks to human extinction.
- Call for international collaboration and guidelines to manage AI in military settings to prevent destructive applications.

items.title: Dubbing is terrible. Can AI fix it?
Trump is buying a Tesla after years of bashing EVs
‘A world without Caesars’: Bluesky CEO takes a swipe at Meta’s Mark Zuckerberg and tech plutocrats
items.author: Jay Graber
items.summary:
- Bluesky CEO Jay Graber criticized Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg at SXSW, wearing a shirt that said ‘Mundus sine Caesaribus’ (A world without Caesars).
- The shirt design mirrored Zuckerberg's previous shirt that read ‘Aut Zuck aut nihil’.
- Graber emphasized the importance of decentralized platforms prioritizing users over profits, stating that users could leave if Bluesky were controlled by a billionaire.
- Bluesky, based on the open-source AT Protocol, has over 33 million users, but is still far from the user base of Meta's platforms, which total 3.35 billion daily active users.

items.title: What comes after search? Cloudflare’s CEO says that’s an ‘existential’ question for the internet
items.author: Anna-Louise Jackson
items.summary:
- Google has simplified finding answers, impacting media companies negatively.
- Matthew Prince, CEO of Cloudflare, emphasizes the need for a new business model for the internet as AI changes search dynamics.
- He notes that content scarcity and monetization are crucial for creators' sustainability against AI systems.
- Cloudflare aims to enhance online information access while ensuring fair compensation for creators.

items.title: Amazon will soon be streaming Trump’s ‘The Apprentice’ reality show
items.summary:
- Amazon will start streaming *The Apprentice* starting Monday, with the first season available now and subsequent seasons airing weekly until late April.
- The show debuted in 2004 and was pivotal in boosting Donald Trump’s public persona and business image.
- Trump highlighted the nostalgic value and learning experiences from the show in a statement released by Amazon.
- This move reflects Amazon's efforts to mend relations with Trump, following a complicated history during his presidency.

items.title: What the breakup of Google could mean for Apple and other tech companies
items.author: Chris Morris
items.summary:
- The Justice Department suggested Google be forced to sell the Chrome web browser following a ruling that determined it was a monopoly.
- Google’s revenue share payment to Apple as the default search engine in Safari was estimated at $20 billion in 2022, impacting Apple's operating profit.
- Apple intervened in the government case against Google but was denied by a judge, raising concerns about future financial dependencies and legal repercussions for other tech companies like Meta and Amazon.

items.title: People are paying up for this $39 yogurt that went viral on TikTok
items.summary:
- A yogurt called Coconut Cult is priced at $39 for a 16-ounce jar and has become a viral trend on TikTok.
- Influencers are promoting its probiotic benefits, reporting improvements in bloating and digestion, but some users criticize its sour taste.
- The yogurt is marketed more as a probiotic supplement rather than a standard snack, containing about 50 billion CFUs per ounce, significantly higher than regular yogurts.
- The product is experiencing high demand, causing shipping delays of up to three weeks as production ramps up to meet this demand.

items.title: 6 free LinkedIn Learning courses to help you find a new job
items.author: Doug Aamoth
items.summary:
- The job market is challenging, with many individuals facing layoffs.
- LinkedIn Learning offers free courses to help job seekers enhance their skills and confidence.
- Six recommended courses include:
  - **Polish up your résumé**: A 2.5-hour course on creating effective résumés, including formatting, keywords, common mistakes, and using action verbs.

items.title: How science is individualizing pregnancy risks
Why we’re ushering in a new era in pregnancy health
items.author: Maneesh Jain
items.summary:
- Lindsay Orr faced preeclampsia during pregnancy, leading to long-term health issues post-delivery.
- U.S. lags behind other nations in addressing the maternal health crisis, with 20% of pregnant women experiencing complications.
- Current prenatal care model has not changed significantly in 100 years, despite rising rates of complications like preeclampsia and preterm birth.
- Mirvie’s study analyzed 11,000 pregnancies, uncovering biological insights to predict risks of pregnancy complications.
- Personalized medicine in pregnancy can improve outcomes and reduce complications through tailored care plans and monitoring methods.

items.title: Tesla stock plummets but its sky-high valuation persists. Here’s why
SEC to abandon plan for crypto firms to register as trading systems
Cybertruck owners are joining a Facebook support group—and want to be a protected class
items.summary:
- Cybertruck owners report experiencing harassment and violence due to their vehicle choice, including threats and mockery.
- One owner has called for congressional action to classify such harassment as a hate crime, citing personal experiences of being targeted.
- A Facebook group for Cybertruck owners shares incidents of attacks, including a video of cheese being thrown at a Cybertruck.
- Police are responsive to the concerns, with reports of police protection at public events involving Cybertrucks.
- Protests against Tesla and Elon Musk have escalated, with calls for Tesla owners to divest from the brand due to Musk's actions.

items.title: How farmers are using AI on vineyards to make wine
Nissan is testing driverless vehicles in city streets
items.author: Yuri Kageyama
items.summary:
- Nissan's driverless technology utilizes 14 cameras, 9 radars, and 6 LiDar sensors installed in its vehicles.
- The technology is being tested in Yokohama, with plans to deploy 20 vehicles in the area in the coming years.
- The current testing stage is categorized as Level Two automation, requiring a human operator to intervene if necessary.
- Nissan aims to reach Level Four automation by 2029 or 2030, allowing for operation without human backup.
- Japan is competing with global leaders in autonomous driving, notably China and the U.S.
- The country faces challenges such as high public expectations for service quality and the need to address safety concerns around driverless technology.
- Prominent figures, including professors in the field, emphasize the importance of addressing edge cases for the future success of autonomous vehicles.

items.title: Social media might be making you sweat—literally
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Researchers from Durham University studied the physiological effects of scrolling social media, particularly Instagram.
- 54 young adults were monitored while browsing Instagram for 15 minutes; heart rates slowed but sweating increased compared to reading a news article.
- Interruptions from scrolling did not help; participants remained stressed and anxious, showing withdrawal-like symptoms similar to those experienced by addicts.
- Over half of Americans plan to reduce phone usage by 2025, with average daily screen time increasing to 5 hours and 16 minutes by 2024.

items.title: HUD is eyeing a crypto experiment. Some government workers are concerned
items.summary:
- The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) is considering using cryptocurrency for federal grants and is exploring blockchain technology for monitoring.
- Concerns are raised among HUD officials about the risks of paying grant recipients in cryptocurrency, highlighting its association with financial speculation and potential harm.
- The proposal is being pushed by HUD's principal deputy CFO, Irving Dennis, with involvement from the consulting firm EY. 
- The blockchain initiative coincides with a pro-crypto stance from the Trump administration, which has shown support for the crypto industry.

items.title: I tried out a bunch of the AI assistants. Here’s what you need to know about each one
items.summary:
- Overview of various AI assistants including ChatGPT, Microsoft Copilot, Google Gemini, Anthropic Claude, DeepSeek, Grok, Perplexity, Duck.ai, and others.
- Each assistant has unique features, integrations, and pricing models.
- Notable features like voice modes, emotion recognition, web search, and document interaction are highlighted for each assistant.
- Pricing ranges from free basic access to premium plans costing up to $30 per month.

items.title: AI Slop is Suffocating the Web, Says a New Study
items.author: Yaohui Zhang
items.summary:
- A new study analyzes over 300 million documents showing AI-generated content on the rise across various sectors.
- Following the release of ChatGPT, AI involvement in customer complaints increased tenfold.
- Certain states like Arkansas and Missouri are more likely to use AI for writing complaints, while others like West Virginia and Vermont show lower usage.
- Researchers developed a statistical framework to detect AI-generated text with over 96.7% accuracy.
- Concerns are raised about AI constraining human creativity due to the overwhelming amount of AI-generated content.

items.title: 3 Simple Ways to Fight Back Against Spam Calls
items.summary:
- Adding your phone number to the [National Do Not Call Registry](https://www.donotcall.gov/index.html) can significantly reduce spam calls. It takes a month for telemarketers to remove you from their lists after registration.
- Utilizing call-blocking features on smartphones can help manage unwanted calls. Most smartphones allow blocking of individual numbers, effective against repeat offenders.
- Additional options may be needed, as the Do Not Call list is often ineffective against scammers and illegal telemarketers.
